Umpa, umpa, stick it up your jumper

This phrase dates back to the Victorian prime of the British music hall tradition. It was used both literally, as a way to hold packages when you walked along, and as a slightly politer version of the American “stick it up your ass”.

“Umpa Umpa (Stick It Up Your Jumper)” was first recorded by comedy duo The Two Leslies in 1935, but was made very famous by Jimmy Edwards' recording in 1950. The chorus has been a popular playground chant ever since.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w7_jz8rTtcw

“Villain, take my Purse
 If ever thou wilt thrive, bury my Body
 And give the Letters which thou findst about me
 To Edmund Earl of Gloucester: seek him out upon the English Party
 Oh, untimely death, death–”
 “I know thee well, a serviceable Villain; as duteous to the Vices of thy Mistress as badness would desire”
 “What, is he dead?”
 “Sit you down, Father; rest you”

These lines were recorded directly off a radio broadcast of King Lear. They are taken from Act 4, Scene 6. Lennon tuned his radio to the BBC Third Program on its final day before becoming Radio 3 and captured these lines quite by chance. They hold no thematic significance but add to the song’s trippy atmosphere.

The opening line is spoken by John Bryning, playing Oswald. The conversation following his death is between Edgar, played by Philip Guard, and Gloucester, played by Mark Dignam.
(Now good sir, what are you?)

During mixing, John was fiddling with a radio that happened to be broadcasting a production of King Lear. He decided to incorporate it into the song. There’s a small sound that appears to be the first indication of the play before the 5th verse but it’s almost undistinguishable, and the production will be picked up again by the end of the song. During this chorus, we get a portion of Act 4, scene 6:


GLOUCESTER
Now, good sir, what are you?

EDGAR
A most poor man, made tame to fortune’s blows;
Who, by the art of known and feeling sorrows,
Am pregnant to good pity.
Everybody’s got one, everybody’s got one

From John Lennon’s 1980 Playboy interview:

PLAYBOY: “What about the chant at the end of the song: Smoke pot, smoke pot, everybody smoke pot'?”
LENNON: “No, no, no. I had this whole choir saying, ‘Everybody’s got one, everybody’s got one.’ But when you get 30 people, male and female, on top of 30 cellos and on top of the Beatles' rock ‘n roll rhythm section, you can’t hear what they’re saying.”
PLAYBOY: “What does 'everybody got’?”
LENNON: “Anything. You name it. One penis, one vagina, one asshole– you name it.”
Man, you’ve been a naughty boy, you let your face grow long

Someone who is frowning is said to have a “long face”. Men are often socially conditioned to “keep a stiff upper lip”, and avoid showing sadness or crying. A few lines later, Lennon defies that by publicly announcing that he’s crying.

“Growing your face long” might also be a poetic reference to growing a beard, an act considered by many to be a sign of rebelliousness.
Goo goo a’joob

The song is essentially nonsense. This line is total gibberish.

People don’t understand. In John’s song, ‘I Am The Walrus’ he says: ‘I am he as you are he as you are me.’ People look for all sorts of hidden meanings. It’s serious, but it’s also not serious. It’s true, but it’s also a joke.

–George Harrison

It has been written that Lennon got the line “Goo Goo Ga Joob” from the book Finnegans Wake by James Joyce. However, the closest approximation in Joyce is “googoo goosth”, which doesn’t quite have the same ring to it.
I am the eggman, I am the eggman

Refers both to Lewis Carroll’s Humpty Dumpty, and a story Lennon heard from The Animals frontman Eric Burdon about a girl cracking an egg onto him during sex.

The words don’t mean a lot. People draw so many conclusions, and it’s ridiculous…‘I am the Eggman?’ It could have been the pudding basin for all I care.
- John Lennon

According to the most commonly told version of the story, Burdon achieved “Eggman” status through his habit of “breaking raw eggs on girls during sex” — but as Burdon himself explained in his 2002 memoir Don’t Let Me Be Misunderstood, it was actually the other way around.

“It may have been one of my more dubious distinctions, but I was the Eggman — or, as some of my pals called me, ‘Eggs,‘” writes Burdon. It all started one sunny morning when he stood in the kitchen, “cooking breakfast naked except for my socks,” and a “Jamaican girlfriend called Sylvia” took it upon herself to send the meal in an entirely different direction.

“She slid up beside me and slipped an amyl nitrate capsule under my nose. As the fumes set my brain alight and I slid to the kitchen floor, she reached to the counter and grabbed an egg, which she cracked into the pit of my belly,” continues Burdon. Long story short, the nickname stuck, and Lennon was thoroughly amused.

“I shared the story with John at a party at a Mayfair flat one night with a handful of blondes and a little Asian girl,” Burdon recalls in his book. “‘Go on, go get it, Eggman,’ Lennon laughed over the little round glasses perched on the end of his hook-like nose as we tried the all-too-willing girls on for size.”
Semolina pilchard

Semolina is a kind of wheat paste. A pilchard is small fish.

It has been speculated that “Semolina Pilchard” was Detective Sergeant Norman Pilcher, head of the Scotland Yard Drugs Unit. He led the arrests of several 60s rock stars, including Lennon, on drugs charges, before being investigated himself for blackmail and bribery in the ‘70s.
Sitting on a cornflake, waiting for the van to come

This is a strange line to glean interpretation, if any, from John Lennon. The van only appeared as a result of Hunter Davies (the Beatles' biographer) mishearing John singing a song fragment.

He’d written down down another few words that day, just daft words, to put to another bit of rhythm. ‘Sitting on a cornflake, waiting for the man to come.’ I thought he said ‘van to come’, which he hadn’t, but he liked it better and said he’d use it instead.
See how they smile like pigs in a sty

A pig’s home is called a “sty”.

It has been speculated that John was inspired by George Orwell’s Animal Farm, an allegorical novella satirizing the Russian Revolution. The main character is a pig, named Napoleon, who writes song and poems of radical propaganda. This is one of the inspirations behind George Harrison’s “Piggies”.
